sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• contains 100 mg calcium chloride per mL; 27.3 mg or 1.36 mEq of elemental calcium per mL
  • Hypocalcemia: 200 mg to 1 g calcium chloride (2 to 10 mL of a 10% solution; 55 to 273 mg elemental calcium) IV every 1 to 3 days; MAX rate, 1 mL/min

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• contains 100 mg calcium chloride per mL; 27.3 mg or 1.36 mEq of elemental calcium per mL
  • Advanced cardiac life support: 20 mg/kg calcium chloride (0.2 mL/kg of 10% solution; 5.5 mg/kg elemental calcium) IV or INTRAOSSEOUS; administer slowly; MAX dose 2 g calcium chloride (546 mg elemental calcium)
  • Hypocalcemia: 2.7 to 5 mg/kg calcium chloride (0.027 to 0.05 mL/kg of a 10% solution; 0.74 to 1.37 mg/kg elemental calcium) IV every 4 to 6 hours; MAX rate, 1 mL/min

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment: CrCl less than 25 mL/min, base dosing on serum calcium levels
  • renal impairment: chronic hemodialysis, dosage reduction may be necessary due to potential for the development of hypercalcemia

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Hypocalcemia
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Advanced cardiac life support
  • General anesthesia; Adjunct

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• use of ceftriaxone sodium injection in neonates receiving or expected to receive calcium-containing IV solutions
  • ventricular fibrillation during cardiac resuscitation

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• concomitant use of digitalis drugs not recommended unless indications are clearly defined
  • IM, subQ, or injection into perivascular tissue may cause necrosis and skin sloughing
  • injection rate greater than 0.5 to 1 mL/min not recommended
  • renal impairment; CNS toxicity, bone toxicity, and tissue loading may result from aluminum accumulation associated with prolonged parenteral administration; premature neonates are at increased risk

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Calcium: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Calcium is an important mineral which is responsible for strong bones and is also used by the body for proper muscle contraction and nerve function.

0.title: Absorption
0.mono:
• Bioavailability, Oral: 4% to 45%
  • Effect of food: Increased absorption

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    do not give by IM or subQ route
  • Intravenous
    • administer as slow IV injection (not to exceed 1 mL/min) through a small needle into a large vein; preferably in a central or deep vein
    • patient should remain recumbent for a short time following injection
  • Intraventricular
    may inject into the ventricular cavity during cardiac resuscitation; avoid injection into the cardiac muscle

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct patients with renal impairment and caregivers of premature neonates to report signs/symptoms of CNS and bone toxicity.
  • Advise patients to report signs/symptoms of extravasation, including necrosis and sloughing.
